abstracts.cdata!:
The Chile Santiago Urban Transport
            Deferred Drawdown Sector Adjustment Loan Project and
            Santiago Urban Transport Sector Adjustment Loan Project
            constitute an adjustment operation comprising a
            single-tranche Sector Adjustment Loan (SECAL) with a DDO
            feature (Deferred Drawdown Option Loan) and a two-tranche
            Sector Adjustment Loan (SECAL). The loans support an ongoing
            and broad program of reforms in the urban transport sector
            in the Metropolitan Area of Santiago. The loans are
            supported by a companion technical assistance loan (Report
            No: 28521-CL) to help facilitate the achievement of reforms
            targeted for second tranche release and to provide technical
            follow-up, monitoring, and strengthening of the
            implementation of the Santiago Urban Transport Reform. The
            main development objectives of the SECALS are to improve the
            level of transport services to the residents (particularly
            low income residents) and businesses, reduce resource costs,
            and increase environmental quality. The specific objectives
            (i) Reduce transport costs in their financial, travel time,
            and environmental dimensions, and increase transport
            efficiency; (ii) Improve the coordination o f public sector
            activities in land use, transport planning, infrastructure
            investment, traffic management, and bus franchising; (iii)
            address urban poverty through improving access to jobs and
            economic opportunities; and (iv) enhance social inclusion
            through improved access to schools, health facilities, and
            wider social interaction. Benefits include (i) efficiency
            improvements that contribute to the city economy and hence
            economic growth; (ii) resource savings from transferring the
            bus flows in major corridors to an exclusive space, the
            reduction of bus vehicle-km on the street system, the
            rationalization of the route network, and the reduction of
            revenue risks from operators; (iii) environmental
            improvements (higher air quality and lower noise); (iv)
            increased quality of service for passengers who live in the
            catchment areas of the metro extensions and the new metro
            line; (v) increased comfort, safety and reliability for bus
            passengers; (vi) comprehensive coverage of bus feeder routes
            particularly in poor neighborhoods;  (vii) savings stemming
            from the implementation of a unified fare system; and (viii)
            reduced use of 'road space' by car drivers
            contributing to a reduction in congestion. The risks of this
            program are deemed modest. Chile's excellent track
            record in economic management, program implementation and
            transparency make the satisfactory completion of the program
            highly likely. Nevertheless, some issues deserving special
            attention include: increases in waiting and access times;
            resistance from existing transit workers and operators
            opposed to a change in the status quo; unsuccessful
            concession tenders for bus services; potential vulnerability
            to negative external events including less favorable
            commodity prices, higher international interest rates,
            adverse regional developments, as well as domestic factors
            such as contingent fiscal liabilities, external indebtedness
            of the corporate sector, and energy supply risks.
